title: Closes #1492: Don't delete cache files on disk; update test.
message:
Closes #1492: Don't delete cache files on disk; update test.

After we manually delete the cache files, WebView will no longer use the disk
cache, which means Focus uses much more network data. Therefore, we no longer
delete the cache.

While erase all the contents of cache/ except the WebView directory to be safe
that files that we don't want to stick around, won't. That being said,
different versions of WebView could store their files in different places and
this change won't help those users - we'll cross that bridge when we come to
it.

I tested the updated test on an Android API 23 & 26 emulator.

Closes #1306: Delete local storage when starting a new browser session.
message:
Closes #1306: Delete local storage when starting a new browser session.

This code is hacky: see below.

We run clean-up on the main thread in order to guarantee we don't accidentally
delete current session data if we run asynchronously. I haven't seen any
problems with this locally but I'm running in an emulator. Alternative solutions
would be:
1. Find another place to delete (UrlInputFragment.onFilter worked before)
2. Run this on a background thread and run the fragment methods after (may need
to then run those on the UIThread). This would at least free the main thread
for UI events.

It creates more inconsistent confusion in our erase strategy. We should revise
this in #1472.

title: Taskcluster/Travis: Use dummy token for non release builds.
message:
Taskcluster/Travis: Use dummy token for non release builds.

There's an "emergency brake" in our release buils: We will crash if
no Adjust token is set. This is to prevent that we release a version
without the token set. However in automation we are running unit tests
that might trigger this code path and therefore crash. To avoid this
we previously set the environment variable for the token to a random
value. We now have to write such a random value to the .adjust_token
file.

task into multiple tasks that run in parallel. As I needed to

builds to automatically only contain the release locales.

which make me confident the conversion was a success.

Closes #838: Dismiss HomeFragment's PopupMenu onDetach.

One undesirable effect of this change: this issue only shows itself when we
.replace the HomeFragment, which happens when we change locales, whose code
only gets called from `onResume`. This means the menu is *briefly* visible when
returning to the app when following the STR in the bug. This is ugly but given
how infrequently I expect this to happen, I think it's fine.

The solution would be to additionally dismiss the PopupMenu in onStop, but:

1. I'm concerned about unforseen side effects from that change
2. For correctness, we'd have to dismiss the PopupMenu in both `onDetach` and
`onStop` which is a little confusing from a code perspective - better to keep
it clean, I think!

title: Correctly track visibility state of MainActivity. (#774)
message:
Correctly track visibility state of MainActivity. (#774)

When clicking the notification to erase the browsing history our BrowsingNotificationService
needs to decide:

* Is the app in the background? Then close it so that we start fresh the next time it is started.
* Is it in the foreground? Then notify it and play the erase animation.

The previous version tracked forground/background state by looking at onResume() and onPause().
This is not correct in all cases: An activity can be visible but not in the foreground (e.g.
another translucent screen is on top). In this case we still want to play the animation and
not (visibly) close the app.

With this patch we now track the state from onStart() and onStop(). Those callbacks are exactly
for this: They are called once an activity becomes visible to the user.

Additionally with this patch we will track the start of a browsing session as a "foreground"
event. This is necessary because since the service could have been removed since the last
foreground event (it's only "ongoing" *during* a session). However we are *always* in the
foreground when starting a browsing session.

title: No longer update currentPageURL in shouldOverrideUrlLoading()
message:
No longer update currentPageURL in shouldOverrideUrlLoading()

This was needed when we used the pre-api21 version of shouldInterceptRequest.
shouldInterceptRequest() is called for the main document before
onPageStarted(). The api21 version of shouldInterceptRequest()
tells us when we're loading the main page, in which case we already
don't do any URL filtering - so there's no need for us to grab
the URL earlier.

shouldOverrideUrlLoading() is also called for iframes, which we definitely
don't want, since that could break whitelisting. (E.g. if you
visit iAmBlocked.foo which loads resources from iAmAlsoBlocked.foo, and
the entitylist allows iAmBlocked to load from iAmALsoBlocked - if
we then load an iframe with data:text/html then requests to iAmAlsoBlocked
will unintentionally break.)

title: Perform blacklisting based on reverse-host matching

Perform blacklisting based on reverse-host matching

The blocklists are purely host based, so it's more efficient to just
match on the host itself (although there is an, as of yet undetermined,
cost to cutting up the URL to obtain the host). This also works better
for some sites where resources might be loaded from the same host
as the site, but where the URL might contain other (blacklisted)
domains.  (This approach also saves us from iterating over the resource
URL which should compensate for the added getHost() call.)

E.g. nzz.ch will load image resources from nzz.ch, but the path
contains a blacklisted aws domain. We still want to load those images.
The old approach would perform a search on the entire URL, which would
result in those images being blocked.
